body_html:
After debugging more into issue which @namrata-ibm had found out, it turned out an issue with NumPy (similar to 12963).

On Intel:

>>> np.sin(np.array([0.0, np.pi / 4.0, np.pi / 2.0], dtype=np.float32))
array([ 0.        ,  0.70710677,  1.        ], dtype=float32)

On zSystems:

>>> np.sin(np.array([0.0, np.pi / 4.0, np.pi / 2.0], dtype=np.float32))
array([ 0.        ,  0.70710683,  1.        ], dtype=float32)

If we do not specify the data type to the array, NumPy is giving same results on both the platforms.
On Intel:

>>> np.sin(np.array([0.0, np.pi / 4.0, np.pi / 2.0]))
array([ 0.        ,  0.70710678,  1.        ])

On zSystems:

>>> np.sin(np.array([0.0, np.pi / 4.0, np.pi / 2.0]))
array([ 0.        ,  0.70710678,  1.        ])

@mrry Please share your thoughts on this.

body:
After debugging more into issue which @namrata-ibm had found out, it turned out an issue with NumPy (similar to [12963](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/pull/12963)).

On Intel:
```
>>> np.sin(np.array([0.0, np.pi / 4.0, np.pi / 2.0], dtype=np.float32))
array([ 0.        ,  0.70710677,  1.        ], dtype=float32)
```
On zSystems:
```
>>> np.sin(np.array([0.0, np.pi / 4.0, np.pi / 2.0], dtype=np.float32))
array([ 0.        ,  0.70710683,  1.        ], dtype=float32)
```


If we do not specify the data type to the array, NumPy is giving same results on both the platforms.
On Intel:
```
>>> np.sin(np.array([0.0, np.pi / 4.0, np.pi / 2.0]))
array([ 0.        ,  0.70710678,  1.        ])
```

On zSystems:
```
>>> np.sin(np.array([0.0, np.pi / 4.0, np.pi / 2.0]))
array([ 0.        ,  0.70710678,  1.        ])
```

@mrry Please share your thoughts on this.
